Experiment Method.Assay Method: solution state NMR and circular dichroism spectroscopies

Material used.Material Source: Recombinant proteins overexpressed in Escherichia coli
Material used.Description: Recombinant proteins were overexpressed in Escherichia coli at 37°C using IPTG to induce cultures at mid-log phase (OD600 of 0.6).

Readout description.Result Description: The L166P mutation leads to severe and global destabilization and unfolding of the protein structure. The far-UV CD spectrum of L166P DJ-1 was characteristic of a highly unfolded polypeptide, with a drastic decrease in secondary structure content compared with that of the wild-type protein. The HSQC NMR spectrum of the L166P mutant is poorly dispersed, indicating a poorly folded and highly flexible ensemble of structures.

The structure of the E64D mutation is nearly unperturbed. The far-UV CD spectrum, the 222-nm CD melting curve, and the two-dimensional NMR proton-nitrogen correlation spectrum of the E64D DJ-1 mutant were all nearly identical to the corresponding data for the wild-type protein.

The M26I mutation shows different degrees of structural perturbation, which are accompanied by a reduction in the thermodynamic stability of the protein. The far-UV CD spectra of the M26I mutant is similar in shape to that of the wild-type protein but reproducibly exhibit a decreased signal amplitude. The M26I mutant also exhibits a decreased ability to dimerize, a decrease in secondary structure, a decreased stability relative to the wild-type protein, and the formation of both an altered dimer and higher order oligomers.

The A104T mutation shows different degrees of structural perturbation, which are accompanied by a reduction in the thermodynamic stability of the protein. The far-UV CD spectra of the A104T mutant is similar in shape to that of the wild-type protein but reproducibly exhibit a decreased signal amplitude. The chemical shift changes caused by this mutation are associated with residues in the C-terminal ends of adjacent β -strands 6, 7, and 11 of the six-stranded sheet; at the N termini of α -helices 3 and 5, which immediately follow strands 6 and 7, respectively; at the N terminus of α -helix 6; and in the middle of α -helix 7.

The D149A mutation shows different degrees of structural perturbation, which are accompanied by a reduction in the thermodynamic stability of the protein. The far-UV CD spectra of the D149A mutant is similar in shape to that of the wild-type protein but reproducibly exhibit a decreased signal amplitude, with the effect being most pronounced for the D149A mutant. Alteration of D149 to alanine leads to shifts in resonances originating from the two other strands in the three-stranded sheet ( β -strands 8 and 9) as well as in strands 11 and 7, located at the adjacent end of the parallel sheet. The loops between α -helix 6 and β -strand 8 and between β -strands 10 and 11 are also affected.

Biological replicates.Description: All CD spectra and melting curves were acquired in at least two independent measurements to ensure reproducibility.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Source: For the wild-type protein, good dispersion is evident in both the proton and nitrogen dimensions, consistent with a well-folded structure. For mutants, chemical shift perturbations above a threshold value of 0.07 ppm, decreased secondary structure content, and reduced thermodynamic stability (lower Tm) indicate abnormal readout.
